messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 47 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Simulating Logspace-Recursion with Logarithmic Quantifier Depth

Paper Abstract: Abstract The fixed-point logic LREC=subscriptLREC\textup{{LREC}}_{=} was developed by Grohe et al. (CSL 2011) in the quest for a logic to capture all problems decidable in logarithmic space. It extends FO+C, first-order logic with counting, by an operator that formalises a limited form of recursion. We show that for every LREC=subscriptLREC\textup{{LREC}}_{=}-definable property on relational structures, there is a constant kùëòk such that the kùëòk-variable fragment of first-order logic with counting quantifiers expresses the property via formulae of logarithmic quantifier depth. This yields that any pair of graphs separable by the property can be distinguished with the kùëòk-dimensional Weisfeiler‚ÄìLeman algorithm in a logarithmic number of iterations. In particular, it implies that a constant dimension of the algorithm identifies every interval graph and every chordal claw-free graph in logarithmically many iterations, since every such graph admits LREC=subscriptLREC\textup{{LREC}}_{=}-definable canonisation.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 47 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 47"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Sherali‚ÄìAdams relaxations and indistinguishability in counting logics",
        "Definable ellipsoid method, sums-of-squares proofs, and the isomorphism problem",
        "Near-optimal lower bounds on quantifier depth and Weisfeiler‚ÄìLeman refinement steps",
        "Choiceless polynomial time",
        "An optimal lower bound on the number of variables for graph identification",
        "Resource allocation with time intervals",
        "Separating LREC from LFP",
        "Lov√°sz meets Weisfeiler and Leman",
        "Finite model theory",
        "Tree canonization and transitive closure",
        "Forestal algebras and algebraic forests (on a new class of weakly compact graphs)",
        "Generalized first-order spectra and polynomial-time recognizable sets",
        "Weisfeiler‚ÄìLehman refinement requires at least a linear number of iterations",
        "Is polynomial time choiceless?",
        "Choiceless logarithmic space",
        "Isomorphism testing for embeddable graphs through definability",
        "Descriptive Complexity, Canonisation, and Definable Graph Structure Theory, volume 47 of Lecture Notes in Logic",
        "The logic of graph neural networks",
        "A linear upper bound on the Weisfeiler‚ÄìLeman dimension of graphs of bounded genus",
        "Logarithmic Weisfeiler‚ÄìLeman identifies all planar graphs",
        "Canonisation and definability for graphs of bounded rank width",
        "Pebble games and linear equations",
        "Testing graph isomorphism in parallel by playing a game",
        "L-recursion and a new logic for logarithmic space",
        "Color refinement and its applications",
        "The iteration number of the weisfeiler-leman algorithm",
        "Capturing logarithmic space and polynomial time on chordal claw-free graphs",
        "Efficient algorithms for interval graphs and circular-arc graphs",
        "Relational queries computable in polynomial time",
        "Languages that capture complexity classes",
        "Descriptive complexity",
        "Finding Hamiltonian circuits in interval graphs",
        "Power and Limits of the Weisfeiler‚ÄìLeman Algorithm",
        "The power of the Weisfeiler‚ÄìLeman algorithm to decompose graphs",
        "Upper bounds on the quantifier depth for graph differentiation in first-order logic",
        "The Weisfeiler‚ÄìLeman dimension of planar graphs is at most 3",
        "Interval graphs: Canonical representations in logspace",
        "Capturing polynomial time on interval graphs",
        "The structure of graphs and new logics for the characterization of Polynomial Time",
        "Elements of finite model theory, volume 41",
        "Walk refinement, walk logic, and the iteration number of the Weisfeiler‚ÄìLeman algorithm",
        "Algorithmic aspects of comparability graphs and interval graphs",
        "Weisfeiler and Leman go neural: Higher-order graph neural networks",
        "Bounded variable logics and counting ‚Äì A study in finite models, volume 9 of Lecture Notes in Logic",
        "Graph minors. I. excluding a forest",
        "The complexity of relational query languages (extended abstract)",
        "An algorithm based on graph theory for the assembly of contigs in physical mapping of dna"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 47 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Simulating Logspace-Recursion with Logarithmic Quantifier Depth, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
